## Description {#details}

Simple representation of a scaled number.

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalednumber">ScaledNumber</a> is a number represented by digits and a scale. It uses simple saturation arithmetic and every operation is well-defined for every value. It&#39;s somewhat similar in behaviour to a soft-float, but is <em>not</em> a replacement for one. If you&#39;re doing numerics, look at <em><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apfloat">APFloat</a></em> instead. Nevertheless, we&#39;ve found these semantics useful for modelling certain cost metrics.

The number is split into a signed scale and unsigned digits. The number represented is <code><a href="#a774bd871787807c5006ac027c6d5e492">getDigits()</a>&#42;2^getScale</code>(). In this way, the digits are much like the mantissa in the x87 long double, but there is no canonical form so the same number can be represented by many bit representations.

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalednumber">ScaledNumber</a> is templated on the underlying integer type for digits, which is expected to be unsigned.

Unlike <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apfloat">APFloat</a>, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalednumber">ScaledNumber</a> does not model architecture floating point behaviour â€“ while this might make it a little faster and easier to reason about, it certainly makes it more dangerous for general numerics.

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalednumber">ScaledNumber</a> is totally ordered. However, there is no canonical form, so there are multiple representations of most scalars. E.g.: <CodeBlock>ScaledNumber(8u, 0) == ScaledNumber(4u, 1)
ScaledNumber(4u, 1) == ScaledNumber(2u, 2)
ScaledNumber(2u, 2) == ScaledNumber(1u, 3)
</CodeBlock>

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalednumber">ScaledNumber</a> implements most arithmetic operations. Precision is kept where possible. Uses simple saturation arithmetic, so that operations saturate to 0.0 or <a href="#a2fd49141f0fc36006080677630d0b1dc">getLargest()</a> rather than under or overflowing. It has some extra arithmetic for unit inversion. 0.0/0.0 is defined to be 0.0. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/any">Any</a> other division by 0.0 is defined to be <a href="#a2fd49141f0fc36006080677630d0b1dc">getLargest()</a>.

As a convenience for modifying the exponent, left and right shifting are both implemented, and both interpret negative shifts as positive shifts in the opposite direction.

Scales are limited to the range accepted by x87 long double. This makes it trivial to add functionality to convert to <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apfloat">APFloat</a> (this is already relied on for the implementation of printing).

Possible (and conflicting) future directions:


<ul>
<li>Turn this into a wrapper around <em><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apfloat">APFloat</a></em>.</li>
<li>Share the algorithm implementations with <em><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apfloat">APFloat</a></em>.</li>
<li>Allow <em><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalednumber">ScaledNumber</a></em> to represent a signed number.</li>
</ul>

### toString() {#a628cc55e3eb3abc28be11f6fb90b948a}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;class DigitsT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>std::string llvm::ScaledNumber&lt; DigitsT &gt;::toString (unsigned Precision=<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalednumberbase/#a688aa1569355f832c6963c66f1a1b9cd">DefaultPrecision</a>)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Convert to a decimal representation in a string.

Convert to a string. Uses scientific notation for very large/small numbers. Scientific notation is used roughly for numbers outside of the range 2^-64 through 2^64.

<code>Precision</code> indicates the number of decimal digits of precision to use; 0 requests the maximum available.

As a special case to make debugging easier, if the number is small enough to convert without scientific notation and has more than <code>Precision</code> digits before the decimal place, it&#39;s printed accurately to the first digit past zero. E.g., assuming 10 digits of precision: <CodeBlock>98765432198.7654... =&gt; 98765432198.8
 8765432198.7654... =&gt;  8765432198.8
  765432198.7654... =&gt;   765432198.8
   65432198.7654... =&gt;    65432198.77
    5432198.7654... =&gt;     5432198.765 
</CodeBlock>

## Private Member Functions

### matchScales() {#a156b8f8fa66ef5dd3d348f90615d0ba2}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;class DigitsT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>ScaledNumber llvm::ScaledNumber&lt; DigitsT &gt;::matchScales (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalednumber">ScaledNumber</a> X)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Adjust two floats to have matching exponents.

Adjust <code>this</code> and <code>X</code> to have matching exponents. Returns the new <code>X</code> by value. Does nothing if <em><a href="#a058c6551de931ee0d8419628dfd06a69">isZero()</a></em> for either.

The value that compares smaller will lose precision, and possibly become <em><a href="#a058c6551de931ee0d8419628dfd06a69">isZero()</a></em>.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/scalednumber-h/#l00644">644</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/scalednumber-h">ScaledNumber.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

## Private Static Functions

### adjustToWidth() {#a241140ccb3c94eacc435dd5f90718732}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;class DigitsT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>static ScaledNumber llvm::ScaledNumber&lt; DigitsT &gt;::adjustToWidth (uint64&#95;t N, int32&#95;t Shift)</>}
  labels = {["inline", "static"]}>
Adjust a number to width, rounding up if necessary.

Should only be called for <code>Shift</code> close to zero.


<SectionUser title="Precondition">
Shift &gt;= MinScale &amp;&amp; Shift + 64 &lt;= MaxScale.
</SectionUser>
